v.v: These are more proverbs of Solomon, copied by the men of Hezekiah, king of Judah.
It is the glory of God to conceal a matter,
Like the heavens are for height and the earth is for depth,
Remove the dross from the silver
Even so, remove wicked people from the presence of the king
Do not honor yourself in the king’s presence
It is better for him to say to you, “Come up here,”
do not bring quickly to trial.
Argue your case between you and your neighbor himself
or else the one who hears you will bring shame upon you
Apples of gold in settings of silver
A gold ring or jewelry made of fine gold
Like the cold of snow at harvest time
Clouds and wind without rain
With patience a ruler can be persuaded
If you find honey, eat just enough—
Do not set your foot in your neighbor’s house too often,
A man who bears false witness against his neighbor
An unfaithful man in whom you trust in a time of trouble
Like a person who takes off a garment in cold weather,
If your enemy is hungry, give him food to eat,
for you will shovel coals of fire on his head
As surely as the north wind brings rain,
It is better to live on a corner of the roof
Like cold waters to one who is thirsty,
Like a fouled spring or a ruined fountain
It is not good to eat too much honey;
A person without self-control
Like snow in summer or rain in harvest,
As the sparrow flitters and the swallow darts when they fly,
A whip is for the horse, a bridle is for the donkey
Do not answer a fool according to his folly,
Answer a fool and join in on his folly,
Whoever sends a message by the hand of a fool
Like the legs of a paralytic which hang down
Like tying a stone in a sling
Like a thorn that goes into the hand of a drunkard
Like an archer who wounds all those around him
As a dog returns to his own vomit,
Do you see someone who is wise in his own eyes?
The lazy person says, “There is a lion on the road!
As the door turns on its hinges,
The lazy person puts his hand into the dish
The lazy person is wiser in his own eyes
Like one who takes hold of the ears of a dog,
Like a madman who shoots burning arrows,
is the one who deceives his neighbor
For lack of wood, the fire goes out;
As charcoal is to burning coals and wood is to fire,
The words of a gossip are like delicious morsels;
Like the glaze overlaying an earthen vessel
One who hates others disguises his feelings with his lips
He will speak graciously, but do not believe him,
Though his hatred is covered with deception,
Whoever digs a pit will fall into it
A lying tongue hates the people it crushes
Do not boast about tomorrow,
Let someone else praise you and not your own mouth;
Consider the heaviness of a stone and the weight of sand—
There is the cruelty of rage and the flood of anger,
Better is an open rebuke
Faithful are the wounds caused by a friend,
A person who has eaten to the full rejects even a honeycomb,
Like a bird that wanders from its nest
Perfume and incense make the heart rejoice,
Do not forsake your friend and your friend’s father,
Be wise, my son, and make my heart rejoice;
A prudent man sees trouble and hides himself,
Take a garment of one who has put up security for a stranger,
Whoever gives his neighbor a blessing with a loud voice early in the morning,
A quarreling wife is like
restraining her is like restraining the wind,
Iron sharpens iron;
The one who tends a fig tree will eat its fruit,
Just as water reflects a person’s face,
Just as Sheol and Abaddon are never satisfied,
A crucible is for silver and a furnace is for gold;
Even if you crush a fool with the pestle—along with the grain—
Be sure you know the condition of your flocks
for wealth is not forever.
You should know when the hay is gone and the new growth appears,
Those lambs will provide your clothing
There will be goats’ milk for your food—the food for your household—
The wicked people run away when no one chases them,
Because of the transgression of a land, it has many rulers,
A poor person who oppresses other poor people
Those who forsake the law praise wicked people,
Evil men do not understand justice,
It is better for a poor person who walks in his integrity,
He who keeps the law is a son who has understanding,
The one who makes his fortune by charging too much interest
If one turns away his ear from hearing the law,
Whoever misleads the upright into an evil way
The rich person may be wise in his own eyes,
When the righteous triumph, there is great glory;
The one who hides his sins will not prosper,
The one who always lives with reverence is blessed,
Like a roaring lion or a charging bear
The ruler who lacks understanding is a cruel oppressor,
If a man is guilty because he has shed someone’s blood,
Whoever walks with integrity will be kept safe,
The one who works his land will have plenty of food,
A faithful man will have great blessings,
It is not good to show partiality,
A stingy man hurries after riches,
Whoever disciplines someone,
Whoever robs his father and his mother and says, “That is no sin,”
A greedy man stirs up conflict,
One who trusts in his own heart is a fool,
The one who gives to the poor will lack nothing,
When the wicked arise, people hide themselves;
A person who has received many rebukes but who stiffens his neck
When righteous people increase, the people rejoice,
Whoever loves wisdom makes his father rejoice,
The king establishes the land by justice,
A man who flatters his neighbor
In the sin of an evil person is a trap,
The righteous person knows the rights of the poor;
Mockers set a city on fire,
When a wise person has an argument with a fool,
The bloodthirsty hate the one who is blameless
A fool reveals all his anger,
If a ruler pays attention to lies,
The poor person and the oppressor are similar,
If a king judges the poor by the truth,
The rod and reproof give wisdom,
When wicked people are in power, transgression increases,
Discipline your son and he will give you rest;
Where there is no prophetic vision the people run wild,
A slave will not be corrected by words,
See a man who is hasty in his words?
One who pampers his slave from youth,
An angry person stirs up strife
A person’s pride brings him low,
One who shares with a thief hates his own life;
The fear of man makes a snare,
Many are those who seek the face of the ruler,
An unjust man is an abomination to righteous people,

v: but the glory of kings to search it out.
so the heart of kings is unsearchable.
and a metal worker can use the silver in his craft.
and his throne will be established by doing what is right.
and do not stand in the place designated for great people.
than for him to humiliate you before a nobleman.
What you have witnessed,
For what will you do in the end
when your neighbor puts you to shame?
and do not disclose another’s secret,
and an evil report about you that cannot be silenced.
is a word spoken in the right situation.
is a wise rebuke to a listening ear.
is a faithful messenger for those who sent him;
he brings back the life of his masters.
is the one who boasts about a gift he does not give.
and a soft tongue can break a bone.
otherwise, having too much of it, you vomit it up.
he may become tired of you and hate you.
is like a club used in war, or a sword, or a sharp arrow.
is like a bad tooth or a foot that slips.
or like vinegar poured upon carbonate of soda,
is the one who sings songs to a heavy heart.
and if he is thirsty, give him water to drink,
and Yahweh will reward you.
so a tongue that tells secrets will result in angry faces.
than in a house shared with a quarreling wife.
so is good news from a far country.
is a righteous person tottering before wicked people.
that is like searching for honor after honor.
is like a city breached and without walls.
